Posts.Content: jas_man wrote: I just had a lumpectomy and cancer has not yet spread to my nodes! Around 2 cm was taken, including the margins. Doctor says I might need to go through just 4 chemo sessions. I'm just so grateful it's still at Stage 1. My 29th birthday is next week and I couldn't ask for a better gift than this and knowing that my friends and family are there behind me  DX 12/08. Lumpectomy 12/15/08 2cm. Stage 1 - Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, negative nodes. ER+/PR+. HER2+. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: just finished lumpectomy.. jas_man jas_man

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 04:10PM jas_man wrote: Thanks Brenda D and Jule. I know that to outsiders the results are pretty safe (I have yet to get the full results of the Oncotype test) but as you mentioned Jule, chemo is pretty much in the agenda for someone my age. I'm sure glad that my surgeon said I might need only 4 sessions. Well, it's a hell lot better than 8 sessions :) I'm still pretty bummed about losing my hair through chemo, but I'm trying to have fun getting a wig and buying some scarves. I'm still trying to perfect the "it's okay" song and dance number whenever people try to hint on my reaction about losing hair.  Over-all, it won't be such a bad birthday and Christmas :) Happy Holidays ladies! :)

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 05:07PM jas_man wrote: It's Day 5 after my 1st TC treatment and I finally feel normal again. Hopefully this lasts longer than a couple of hours so that I can go back to work in a few hours. I finally managed to eat a real meal last night (Chicken Kebabs at a Mediterannean place) and 2 Krispy Kreme donuts in  the past 8 hours. Talk about catching up on lost calories! :P My anti-nausea meds run out today so hopefully I won't have the dizzy and puking feeling I had yesterday. Only concern I have right now is constipation. I've been taking Senekot at least once a day for the past 2 days and I've managed to do well but how long do I take it?? Any other way to "let it all out"?? :D
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 09:36PM jas_man wrote: Webwriter,  Yes, I did have SNB and thank God it was negative! It's becoming really uncomfortable right now, keep forgetting to wear an unwired bra! So when the roads get bumpy, I try to hold on to my breast LOL! Will try to elevate my arm while sleeping. In the meantime, good thing that it's cold and I need to wear long-sleeves, it makes the shafing feeling less pronounced. Happy New Year! :P
Posts.Title: Fluid build-up after lumpectomy... jas_man baburabe

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 08:45PM jas_man wrote: It's Day 17 after my first chemo session and my hair is starting to shed. My wig is ready, I have tons of bandannas but no matter how much I've prepared, I don't think I'm ready to go bald yet.. :( I've always had falling hair, but today, it is falling non-stop. I have to frequently pick up stray hair on my shirt, on the table.. everywhere! And I get so sad when i get clumps of hair out because my hair is so thin on a normal day. Just wanted to rant... I didn't expect this hair issue to be so confusing for me...
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 11:58AM jas_man wrote: Gosh, I sound so vain but I'm starting to get worried that my hair won't last in the next 3 days. I have a presentation 2 days from now and chemo right after in the afternoon. I don't want to be thinking about hair right now. I wanted to wait until right after chemo to decide whether to shave it all off or try to hold on to it as long as possible. Went out with my boyfriend this evening and the shedding was really irritating. He and I had a good laugh about it but the frequent cleaning up of strands started to annoy me at some point. I'm "trying on" my bandannas every night since 2 days ago to get a feel of it and I'm starting to enjoy it since it keeps everything in place. I hope I get over this hair thing soon since it's starting to sound like an obsession.. :P I'm so glad that I have all the Jan jewels sharing thoughts and ideas on this hair loss thing. It keeps me strong and gives me hope that eventually this will be a minor thing in this BC fight..
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: jas_man wrote: I just went through a lumpectomy 2 weeks ago. Since then, I've had my BS aspirate twice to remove the fluid... around 10-20cc per aspiration. I'm out of the country right now and my operated breast is feeling sore and hard. I'm not sure if there is fluid again or if it is just sore because I accidentally bumped in to a shoe box while shopping yesterday LOL :P My BS said most patients need just 1 or 2 aspirations max. Nevertheless, she gave me some syringes that my mom can use to aspirate (she is also a doctor). How many times did you have to aspirate?   DX 12/08. Lumpectomy 12/15/08 2cm. Stage 1 - Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, negative nodes. ER+/PR+. HER2+. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Fluid build-up after lumpectomy... jas_man baburabe

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 01:22AM jas_man wrote: Hi webwriter.. Sorry, I'm kinda a novice with the terminologies so I'm not too sure what SNB and ALDN stands for... I just know that a lump was taken out LOL. I slept wearing a sports bra for about 3 days after surgery. But sleeping braless sure felt better.. :)  Since then I've managed to move my arm "normally", meaning I was able to raise it to take off and put on my shirt around 3-5 days after surgery. The "underbelly" of my arm (not exactly the armpit) is very sensitive, a bit prickly, sort of like a shafing sensation. My BS said to rub it occassionally to get it used to the pressure. My BS is female and she is kinda cool. After asking her if it would be okay to drink alcohol given the Christmas party season..  she said, "Go! Have fun! Drink as much as you can. Once you start chemo you can't drink anymore!". Made me sad to hear that but I did follow her advice. LOL! Hi Barb, I'd be sooo bothered if I heard a sloshing sound. I'm between a cup A and B so I'm not sure if the size has anything to do with how much fluid can be stored in the breast. =P Sometimes, I do feel a sloshing motion, but in the upper back side of my arm, not in the breast. Sounds weird eh? Not so sure what's normal and weird anymore since I found out I have BC about a month ago... :P
Posts.Title: Fluid build-up after lumpectomy... jas_man baburabe

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 09:11PM jas_man wrote: JustSaying... My BS  said that they do recommend that you wear a sports bra right after surgery. It keeps "things" in place.  I share the same feeling with regard to the soreness, although not exactly in the armpit area. I think this is because of the lymph node surgery. I'm 2 weeks past my lumpectomy and SNB and it is still sore. Not as numb as before and I think judging from webwriter's comments, the shafing sensation is a common side effect. Just take things one day at a time. 3 days after surgery, I've managed to slightly raise my arm, not much difficulty in taking of my shirt. It's been 2 weeks now and I can take off my bra snap from behind with both arms. My BS said that I can drive in 3-5 weeks, by that time I'll probably have a better range of motion on my arm. Don't try to force it, I think your progress will depend on your day to day activities.
Posts.Title: Fluid build-up after lumpectomy... jas_man baburabe

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 09:41PM jas_man wrote: Hi Snowbird - I bought a box of Throat Coat in Target and it costs less than $5. It tastes surprisingly good... tea-ish but with a sweet after taste. :) With regard to hair loss, just want to take a poll on how many ladies opted to shave their heads once hair loss began vs those who tried to prolong having hair by getting a really short cut.. I already ordered my wig (human hair) but having second thoughts with shaving once my hair falls off...  Any thoughts? Thanks! :)
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 12:43PM jas_man wrote: I just finished 2 out of my 4 TC treatments and I can say that the 2nd treatment had worst SE than the 1st one. I was nauseous by the 2nd day but nothing would come out! Even when I was asleep, I could feel myself wanting to throw up! I hope the 3rd wouldn't be as bad.  I finally had my hair really shortened. My stylist didn't want to give me a buzz cut, he instead gave me a Rihanna cut. He wanted to give me "layers" to hide the bald spots so that I could still walk around the house without a scarf/bandanna on.. LOL. I humored him but wished that he cut it a bit shorter because I'm still shedding and I find the strands still too long. I'm having my wig adjusted tomorrow since I look like Dora the Explorer. My stylist tried to give justice to the wig by giving me a bob cut with layers but it just doesn't fit right! It gets hot and itchy. Sometimes I think I can pull off a bandanna look and just leave the wig at home. I'm praying the weeks go by quickly. After the 4th treatment, my hair can start growing back. I can't wait! I can't believe I've taken for granted the way we run our hands through our hair, or how we haphazardly tie a ponytail... Hmmm, I truly am obsessed... ;) I guess this is just my way of coping with BC.. :)
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2008 08:45AM jas_man wrote: Hi Everyone! My name is Jas, 29 y.o. (today's my birthday !) and I just had a lumpectomy last week. Diagnosis is Invasive Ductal Carcinoma with lymphovascular invasion. Tumor taken out was around 2 cm and 2 nodes for sentinel node biopsy. Results show that no node involvement, so still Stage 1.... thank God! However, given that there is lymphovascular invasion, my BS was saying they would normally recommend 6 sessions, instead of 4. Have yet to meet with my oncologist, last day for consultation was today and I couldn't get in an appointment, so I don't really know yet the details of my chemo. I will meet up with him next year and will definitely start mid-Jan. I will be going to the U.S. on the 25th so I've listed down every recommended item for chemo that I can't find here. I'm soo glad to be part of a group that will more or less go through the same experience with me next year :)  Happy Holidays to everyone!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 11:38PM jas_man wrote: It's Day 3 after my 1st chemo session (1 out of 4 TC sessions) and I'm feeling slightly better. Day 1 was a no visible side effect day, slightly tired in the afternoon but I managed to entertain a guest. Day 2 was like slowdown day for me. I practically slept the whole day! Had some minor muscle pain but nothing the meds couldn't conquer. Wasn't able to eat much yesterday since the idea of oily/greasy food made me a bit queasy. My appetite is coming back today but still can't eat that much. How long does the SE last? I plan to go back to work tomorrow but if this tiredness I'm feeling is still there, I might have to stay home tomorrow.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 06:13PM jas_man wrote: Hi Everyone! I finally met with my onc the other day and since my DX was stage 1, neg nodes, clear margins but ER/PR+ and HER2+ , here are the treatments he's recommending: 4 rounds of TC (thank God it's just 4!) Herceptin for 1 year Tamoxifen for 5 years Since my estrogen receptiveness is quite high, he's also recommending that I stop my period by giving me shot (I forget the name of the med, starts with a L). Since I'm only 29 and single, he's asking me to think about it because there is no assurance that my period will ever come back. Hence, the possibility of never having kids. The tamoxifen is a bummer because i can't have kids for 5 years, but at least with that, I know I may start trying after 5 years. My friends tell me to think about saving my life first before thinking of another life. If it's meant to be, my period will come back. I'm starting to think that way as well. I'm just asking God to give me a sign... This is a major dilemma for me and any experience or inputs on this will really help me a lot. Do let me know your thoughts on this..
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2009 04:23AM jas_man wrote: carpediem - For about a week after my hair started falling off, my scalp itched like crazy! I had rashes too. What I did was to switch to Tea Tree shampoo from baby shampoo. My hair has slowed down on shedding so I'm not sure if that's the reason why the itchiness is subsiding or if the tea tree is working. Anyway, wouldn't hurt to try it out. The tea tree feels all tingly after shampooing, so that's one benefit from using it :)
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 01:05PM jas_man wrote: Hi Kaiselina.. I was diagnosed with idc 2 weeks after I found a lump on my left breast while showering. It would have been sooner but I found on the last few days of my period. I was 28 at that time and felt really young to have BC. To ease your worries, I would suggest to at least get an ultrasound, then a biopsy after if it looks highly suspicious. No use waiting for 3 months. What for?? If it's fibrocystic, then no prob. But what if it's malignant? Not scaring you but wouldn't you want to find out sooner? Anyway, ultrasound and biopsy are painless. Biopsy was something I was dreading but took less time than the ultrasound, which was slightly uncomfortable and embarassing because  your breasts are exposed and gelled to the max! But after the doctor was called in by the technician, I couldn't care less if he wanted to put peanut butter then rub it in with his hands!   I wish you all the best and hope that this is nothing to be worried about ... :)
Posts.Title: How old can you get breast cancer? kaiselina miss-di
